results.headline: Review: ‘Burnt,’ With Bradley Cooper as a Chef Fresh From Rehab

results.headline: Review: In ‘Insiang,’ a Filipino Woman Suffers in the Slums
results.summary_short: This drama follows the misfortunes of a woman living a difficult existence in the poor section of Manila.

results.headline: Review: ‘Paranormal Activity: The Ghost Dimension’: Goodbye to All That
results.summary_short: The lucrative horror series adds a specter to Christmas, and bows out.

results.headline: Review: ‘The Pearl Button,’ a Reflection on Chile’s Coast and Loss
results.summary_short: The Chilean filmmaker Patricio Guzmán is known for his nonfiction movies about the dictatorship of Augusto Pinochet.

results.headline: Review: In ‘Nasty Baby,’ Friends Decide to Start a Family. What Could Go Wrong?
results.summary_short: With its haute Bohemian locations and its hectic, hand-held style — this film by Sebastián Silva presents itself as something familiar.

results.headline: Review: ‘Bone Tomahawk’ Is Western, Horror and Comedy
results.summary_short: A motley band of gunslingers sets out to rescue innocents from cannibals. But don’t count them out: Their leader is Kurt Russell.

results.headline: Review: ‘Tokyo Tribe,’ Sion Sono’s Hip-Hop Musical
results.summary_short: A near-future Tokyo is ruled by rival gangs that dance, run and fight in the latest film from this Japanese provocateur.

results.headline: Review: ‘The Last Witch Hunter,’ Holding a Grudge for 800 Years
results.summary_short: Vin Diesel has been doing battle with an evil queen since medieval times, and their animosity has just become nastier.

results.headline: Review: ‘Jem and the Holograms’ Are Shadows of Their Former Selves
results.summary_short: “Jem and the Holograms,” once an animated series, has been thawed out and refashioned into a movie.

results.headline: Review: In ‘The Looking Glass,’ an Aging Actress Mentors a Troubled Granddaughter
results.summary_short: Two generations try to connect in this film, starring Dorothy Tristan, who also wrote the film, and is directed by her husband, John Hancock.

results.headline: Review: In ‘Suffragette,’ Feminist Insight That’s About More Than the Vote
results.summary_short: The film takes place in Britain in 1912 and pointedly tells an unfinished story, one that ends on a bittersweet, equivocal note.

results.headline: Review: ‘India’s Daughter’ Explores a Gang Rape and Its Galvanizing Aftermath
results.summary_short: This documentary from Leslee Udwin examines the case of a student who was raped and dumped by the side of a road in India.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of India's Daughter

results.headline: Review: ‘Extraordinary Tales,’ Short Films Inspired by Edgar Allan Poe
results.summary_short: This movie strings five animated short films into a curiosity of torture, murder, pestilence and madness.

results.headline: Review: ‘Difret’ Confronts Sexism in Ethiopia
results.summary_short: This docudrama centers on a girl who is taken in by a lawyer after being charged with murder for shooting a man who tried to kidnap her for the purpose of marriage.

results.headline: Review: ‘Crumbs,’ a Post-Apocalyptic World Clings to Pop Culture
results.summary_short: Ninja Turtles, Michael Jackson records and sports celebrities are the crumbs of civilization that hold what’s left of the world in thrall, in this feature debut by Miguel Llansó.

results.headline: Review: In ‘Rock the Kasbah,’ Who Cares About War When There’s Money to Be Made?
results.summary_short: Bill Murray plays a has-been music promoter in Los Angeles who finds himself in Afghanistan,placing a young woman on an Afghan TV talent show.

results.headline: Review: ‘I Smile Back’ Traces a Mother’s Addiction
results.summary_short: Sarah Silverman stars as a housewife caught in a downward spiral in this movie based on a 2008 novel by Amy Koppelman.

results.headline: Review: ‘Heart of a Dog,’ Laurie Anderson’s Meditation on Loss
results.summary_short: The performance artist reflects on the deaths in her life, including that of her husband, Lou Reed, and her rat terrier, Lolabelle.

results.headline: ‘Jason and Shirley’ Reimagines the Making of a Landmark Documentary
results.summary_short: Stephen Winter speculates what happened behind the camera in the 1967 documentary “Portrait of Jason,” about a gay African-American hustler.

results.headline: Review: ‘Jane B. par Agnès V.’ Unites Director and Subject
results.summary_short: This documentary, released in 1988 and now having its American premiere, is the result of a deep collaboration between the director Agnès Varda and the actress Jane Birkin.
